caption: A photograph showing “kill markings” that indicate flying saucers on the side of a German World War II anti-aircraft gun

result.explanation: The image clearly shows a German World War II anti-aircraft gun.  The caption mentions "kill markings" indicating flying saucers, which are not present in the image. Therefore, while the entities related to the gun are accurate, the part about "kill markings" and flying saucers is incorrect.

candidates.title: Is Photo of WWII-Era German Tank That Shot Down UFOs Real?
candidates.content:
Claim:
A photograph shows UFO "kill markings" on the side of a German World War II anti-aircraft gun.
Rating:
False
About this rating
A photograph purportedly showing "kill markings" that indicate flying saucers on the side of a German World War II anti-aircraft gun has been showing up on the internet for several years, often used as proof that unidentified flying objects are a part of the historical record because a "German tank shot down a UFO":
This digitally manipulated image has been circulating since at least 2013 when it was published in the "Humor" section of the Mod DB web forum under the title "I never though the Flak 88 were THAT versatile."
While the photograph does show a German Flak 88mm anti-aircraft gun, the UFO markings were not part of the original photograph:
The original photograph was lifted from the cover of a 1943 issue of Der Adler, a Nazi propaganda magazine:
The caption identified the kill markings on the weapon as 11 planes, 40 armored tanks, and 15 anti-aircraft forts. There was no mention of UFOs.
candidates.description: A photograph purportedly showing kill markings that indicate flying saucers on a WWII-era anti-aircraft gun has been digitally manipulated.

result.explanation: The provided evidence directly contradicts the news caption.  Snopes explicitly states that the photograph showing "kill markings" indicating flying saucers on a German WWII anti-aircraft gun is digitally manipulated. The original photo showed kill markings for conventional targets (planes, tanks, anti-aircraft forts), not UFOs. The manipulated image has been circulating online for years and is considered false.
result.supporting_points: Source 1: Snopes article explicitly debunks the claim, stating the image is digitally manipulated and the original photo contained no mention of UFOs.  The original photo depicted markings for conventional military targets.

final_result.explanation: Both internal and external validation processes strongly indicate that the original caption is out of context. The internal check reveals a mismatch between the image content (a German WWII anti-aircraft gun) and the caption's claim of "kill markings" indicating flying saucers.  The absence of such markings in the image directly contradicts the caption's assertion.  The external check further reinforces this conclusion by citing a Snopes article that definitively debunks the claim.  Snopes confirms that the image circulating with the flying saucer claim is a digitally manipulated version of an original photograph. The original image, according to Snopes, displayed kill markings for conventional military targets, not UFOs. The high confidence scores (10) from both internal and external checks, coupled with the corroborating evidence from Snopes, leave no room for doubt.  There is a complete lack of alignment between the image's actual content and the caption's description.  The caption's fabrication regarding flying saucer kill markings is clearly established. The weight of evidence overwhelmingly supports the conclusion that the caption is entirely out of context, and there's no basis to challenge this conclusion.  No ambiguity or uncertainty exists in this evaluation. Both checks align perfectly, leading to a highly certain conclusion. The entity analysis strengthens the conclusion by confirming the presence of a German WWII anti-aircraft gun, directly supporting the accurate part of the caption, while also confirming the absence of evidence supporting the false claim about UFO kill markings.
final_result.validation_summary: Both internal and external validation processes strongly support the conclusion that the caption is out of context. The image shows a German WWII anti-aircraft gun, but lacks any evidence of "kill markings" indicating flying saucers as claimed in the caption. External verification through Snopes confirms the image is digitally manipulated and the caption is false.
